etymology.interpretation: Food/meal semantic component marks a culinary sense. The phonetic 屯 supplies the pronunciation tún and ties it to its phonetic family. In usage it refers to wontons, a kind of small dumpling commonly eaten in soup.
etymology.simplification: Traditional 飩 was simplified by reducing the semantic component 食 to the radical form 饣; the phonetic component 屯 was kept unchanged.

examples.chinese: 今天中午我点了一碗馄饨汤(今天中午我點了一碗餛飩湯)。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān zhōngwǔ wǒ diǎn le yì wǎn húntun tāng.
examples.english: I ordered a bowl of wonton soup for lunch.

examples.chinese: 上海的馄饨皮薄馅多(上海的餛飩皮薄餡多)，味道很鲜(味道很鮮)。
examples.pinyin: Shànghǎi de húntun pí báo xiàn duō, wèidào hěn xiān.
examples.english: Shanghai-style wontons have thin wrappers and lots of filling, and they taste very fresh.

examples.chinese: 他喜欢在家自己包馄饨(他喜歡在家自己包餛飩)，配上香醋和辣油(配上香醋和辣油)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xǐhuān zài jiā zìjǐ bāo húntun, pèi shàng xiāngcù hé làyóu.
examples.english: He likes to wrap wontons at home, served with aromatic vinegar and chili oil.
